DIV1.P: APRIL-DAY, A BURLETTA, IN THREE ACTS.
WRITTEN BY THE AUTHOR of MIDAS.
AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN THE HAY-MARKET.
THE MUSIC composed by Dr. ARNOLD
LONDON: Printed for G. KEARSLY, No. 46, FLEET-STREET.

DIV1.HEAD: Extract of a Letter from the AUTHOR, to his Friend in LONDON.
DIV1.P:
THE Interlude of the Magic Gir∣dle, which Mr. Barthelemon left in my hands for correction, furnished me with the first hint of this Drama. I send you the original, that you may see my great reserve in borrowing from it; at the same time, humbly begging pardon of the gentleman, unknown, with whose hasty sketch I have taken so many liberties. This
Plot is here totally changed, and his Personages thrown into a different cast of character: I have availed my∣self but very sparingly of his words; scarce at all of his poetry.
I hope he will have the goodness to forgive me for what I have re∣tained and what I have rejected, as∣suring him that, he is welcome to use still greater licence with any work of mine.

I adopt the laconic Dialogue of Italian Burletta, in order to comprise my Fable within the narrow limits of late prescribed by the taste of your audiences. This is short enough to
admit their being indulged with some popular Petite Piece after it.

LIST.ITEM: Don Buffalo, a foolish, swag∣gering, cowardly knave, supposed Guardian to Ce∣phisa. Mr. BANNISTER.
Count Folatre, A young Gentle∣man of worth, Cephisa's lover. Mr. DU-BELLAMY
Davo, Folatre's servant, Intriguing and Trusty. Mr. EDWIN.
Cephisa, A young heiress in love with Fo∣latre. Miss TWIST.
Matilda, Cephisa's maiden aunt, indulgent and chearful. Mrs. HITCHCOCK.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a Chamber—MATILDA and CEPHISA, at the Tea Table.

L.HI: And on the fragrant lymph regale!
Hail Tea! thy grateful soothing steam
As sugar sweet, and soft as cream.
Perch'd on the margin of each cup
Hymen the nuptial torch lights up.
Drink Tea, ye brave and fair!
Drink Tea, ye brave and fair!

DIV2.STAGE: They rise and come forward laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: But apropos, child!—This same Hy∣men's torch—

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Yes, think—come, tell not me;—you girls, do think,
And oft'times think, the hours of celibacy

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Unless you think on't young, when old, you'll think,
And not be thought upon—why, here stand I now.

L.HI: I, in my giddy days—yes, I
Yet, was so nice, forsooth—so shy—
I scorn'd to fix on any.
But now from my tantrums emerging,
And am, to my grief a stale virgin.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.P: Why, the case is piteous; (sighing) But you, my dear! are, by your father's will, Secur'd against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.L: That—"if within the year no match be offer'd,
"Shou'd grant consent, I must, perforce, consent

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Further—"if you refuse, then your whole fortune

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Choose quickly, then—you've but this night to choose in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.L: That is, I wish—but no—and yet—a maiden—

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.P: Well judg'd! tho' both, perhaps, you yet might shun.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: I'll try her— (to her) pray Cephisa!
Last Sunday, in the circus, from our win∣dow—

L.HI: And how gracefully flourish'd his lash!
All the rest seem'd but trash;
To the youth in the sash.

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.L: A pair of dap∣pled greys! I think, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.L: If this Folatre, with the dappled greys,

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.P: Why—no—yes—can't you guess?—in short, dear aunt—

L.HI: That, how to get out o' this pucker,

LG.L: Unless you afford me your succour.—

L.HI: As the light of my eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: A clue, indeed.—Their flame, I find is mutual!
Equal their trust in me—I'll not forsake them—
Our don's a dolt, a vain chick-hearted bully:
His pride, with slatt'ry first, I'll sooth: that fail∣ing,
His fear I will alarm. Next, on his folly,
By stratagem, I'll practise—hush! I hear him—

DIV2.STAGE: (Buffalo is heard blustering behind the scene.)

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.L: Hoa! Dunberblixen, charge my blunderbuss—my rapier, Scolopendroz!
SP.STAGE: Enter a scald Ragamuffin, who kneels, and presents him a sword, then sneaks off, trembling; he draws it arrogantly.
SP.L: Now, by thy blade, thy fate-dispensing blade!
What Caitiff grins this day, shall grin in—death.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.STAGE: (laughing then advances with a low curtsy)
SP.L: With all humility I crave an audience.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Signior, to you, as guardian of Cephisa,
Is now arriv'd at marriageable years— (curtsy)

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Then, Signior, is it your good pleasure
To doom her to the veil?

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: She listens to the vows of—Count Folatre?

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.L: My will—is reason—and my will it is,

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.P: Yea, to the first, my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.L: To set contesting princesses at variance.

L.HI: Lives there—whose valour, blood, and talents,
To Buffalo must vail the bonnet,
To whom, for lineage high, Nassau

LG.L: Must strike the flag, and yield the pas.

DIV2.STAGE: (He swaggers, she eyes him with the utmost dis∣dain, then breaks out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Valour!—thou whipping post! va∣lour! —where slept it,
When on the grand parade, this same Folatre
Can'd you? and tweak'd your nose?

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.L: That Buffalo delib'rates, ere he acts.

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.L: So, while I mus'd, his rashness,
How with due dignity—best to chastise,

L.HI: That he can claim no share in't.
He quakes, if I but frown.

P.HI: You frown on him! you daren't.

L.HI: He's a pet of your niece's;
That tongue yo' 'ad best rein in—

P.HI: By Styx, when I meet him, I'll beat him.
Yet, let me intreat you! not eat him.

L.HI: You may find him plaguy tough.
I shall find him, that's enough.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. The Street before BUFFALO's house.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter COUNT FOLATRE, his servant DAVO follow∣ing. They walk along, looking up to the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Davo.
SP.P: Her aunt, my Lord, comes forth.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter MATILDA, dissatisfied. FOLATRE runs to meet her.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.P: Count! your proposals I tender'd to the Don.

SP.SPEAKER: Fola.
SP.P:
Himself! (in dejection) I'm lost—ay, this I fear'd. She—
She's a treasure Not to be yeilded.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.P: Do, Count? rouse! use your wits! Use stratagem, disguise! Our oaf's a subject For any, any practice.

L.HI: Make a chaos in my breast.
O Jove! vers'd in am'rous wile,

DIV2.STAGE: FOLATRE plung'd in meditation, DAVO steps forward bowing.

SP.SPEAKER: Davo.
SP.P: Pardon my lord—I see you're pos'd— permit me
Madam—I'm told, This Don has faith in the Black Art.

SP.SPEAKER: Davo.
SP.L: On that I build—I play the Astrologer:
You puff me off t'him;—he comes to consult me.
If my resonses make him not as eager

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.P: 'Twill make the fool run mad—I'll call Cephisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Fola.
SP.P: Dispatch good Davo! run man! hire a chamber, Provide your properties.—

L.HI: Dancer of puppets have I been,
If some or other of these shapes,
I've an imp in my sleeve

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.P: My aunt informs me—you've a plot in hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Fola.
SP.L: We have, my angel!—One, on whose event

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.STAGE: (with tenderness, half aside, with a sigh)

DIV2.STAGE: AIR, DUETT, which changes to a TRIO, and afterwards a QUARTETTO.

L.HI: Say, maid ador'd! Say! Heavenly Fair!
Honour can grant, and love demand.

P.HI: They claim—in me they claim—your hand.

L.HI: The little all I can, I give.

P.HI: And I, as heav'ns best boon, receive.

L.HI: And wise are they, who fly.
The man who pull'd your nose.
The man who pull'd your nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.P: This arm, who, (drawing and moving towards him) &c.

L.HI: Stripling, you owe to the police
That bloodless, I resheath my sword;
For I'm bound over to the peace.

P.HI: A good come off, upon my word!

L.HI: Ay, you can now be brave.

DIV2.STAGE: Exit Buffalo, and afterwards the others.
SCENE, A Chamber, Buffalo solus, musing,

SP.SPEAKER: Buss
SP.L: (feigns) Sa, sa! There I could drill him.— Puts up.
Get him laid under an arrest:

L.HI: How great a blessing to my foes,
That, when my wrath could tear'em,
For my ward, fame, and bones.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Matilda, as out of breath.

L.HI: To be out o' th' way,
Where a plague could you stay?
I but to the Conj'ror stept,
Newly slipt down from the regious
He told me the secrets of all my past life:
He told me how oft' I might have been a wife;
Told how this Knight wheedled, and how that Lord swore,
He told me whut follow'd, told what went before;
At last, in a whisper, he told something more,

DIV2.STAGE:
RECITATIVE.
Buff. (aside, ruminating)
This is past coz'nage, no juggling here. (To her, looking wise)
Astrology was ever held a science.
Inscrutable, infallible, incredible.
Such hold it I, and therefore hold firm faith in't.
Matil. (cajoling him)
Most justy reason'd, Signior!
Buff. (flattered)
Yes, I propose
To commune with this Sage, from him to learn
All, what my love, or fortunes may concern.— (Going, stops)
AIR.
Yet, what need I
Consult the sky,
On stars above dependant?
Are not Cephisa's eyes
My stars, my destinies,
And lords of my ascendant?
Exit.
DIV2.P: As Buffalo goes out, enter (at another Door) Cephisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.L: Lord, Aunt! I thought your conf'rence with the Don
Would never end. Where went he?

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: To perfect a small bond to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Yes, poor ten thousand crowns, con∣dition'd solely
That I win you, to place your love on him,
And to discard the Count; that's all. Now, Cephisa!

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.L: And you—you to betray me?—'tis too much.

L.HI: Like her slave, or her beast;

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.L: Nay more, we have a plot to terrify him.
Davo will boast the powers of magic art,
And thus disguis'd so work upon his fears,
That he shall trembie at the thoughts of marriage,
And beg Folatre to accept your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ceph.
SP.L: I'll follow, to be ready at the landing.
(with emotion) Why palpitates my heart? do I not see
That this clod's pride, and fear, and superstition,
All op'rate to our aid? (sighs) wou'd 'twere well over!

L.HI: Of shelves, shoas, winds, and seas.
My cargo's love; wedlock, my port;

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.

SP.SPEAKER: MATIL.
SP.P: THESE are the conj'ror's chambers. Here I leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Matil.
SP.P: He sees but one at once—good stars t'ye!

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.P: Unseen, to know and name me—Strange indeed!

Their aid-de-camp—Me, the bear's arctic, ca∣tarctic,
Saturnus, Urnus, Ops, Hydrops, Libra, Zebra,
(Wi' the rest of the menagerie celestial)

SP.SPEAKER: Buff.
SP.STAGE: (in a tremulous voice, and bowing low)—

SP.SPEAKER: Davo.
SP.L: Occult, incult, difficult, excult, I fathom;

SP.SPEAKER: Davo.
SP.L: I can erect, deject, detect, direct,

LG.L: Sage Daemogorgon, central point of science!

SP.SPEAKER: Davo.

SP.P: But an April masque—I play'd the Daemon!
